message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical signs and examination findings suggest pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophic muscularis externa. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization would result in duodenal atresia or stenosis, which would present with bilious vomiting. Failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum leads to Hirschsprung disease, which presents with constipation and abdominal distension. Telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel, or intussusception, typically presents with abdominal pain and bloody stools.

We refer to medical resources online. The symptoms and physical examination suggest the most likely diagnosis is infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), which is caused by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the muscularis externa of the pylorus, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization would cause duodenal atresia, which presents with duodenal obstruction and is usually diagnosed immediately after birth. Failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum would cause Hirschsprung's disease, which presents with failure to pass meconium, constipation, and abdominal distention in neonates. Telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel would cause intussusception, which presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, and bloody stool in infants and toddlers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped epigastric mass, and delayed capillary refill suggests pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophic muscularis externa. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization results in duodenal atresia, failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum results in Hirschsprung's disease, and telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel results in intussusception, but these conditions do not present with an epigastric mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical findings suggest hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophic muscularis externa of the pylorus. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization will cause duodenal atresia, failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum will cause Hirschsprung's disease, and telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel will cause intussusception, none of which fit the described symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as projectile vomiting, palpable mass, and delayed capillary refill, suggest pyloric stenosis. Among the options, only hypertrophic muscularis externa of the pylorus would cause pyloric stenosis. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization may cause duodenal atresia, failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum may cause Hirschsprung's disease, and telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel may cause intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of projectile vomiting, a palpable epigastric mass, delayed capillary refill, and the absence of bile in vomit suggest pyloric stenosis, caused by hypertrophic muscularis externa. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization is associated with duodenal atresia, and failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum is associated with Hirschsprung disease. Telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel is associated with intussusception, which usually presents with bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of projectile vomiting, non-bloody and non-bilious vomitus, and palpable epigastric mass suggests the most likely diagnosis is hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. This occurs when the muscular wall of the pylorus becomes enlarged and causes obstruction of the stomach's outflow tract leading to vomiting. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization would present with bilious vomiting. Failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum would present with failure to pass meconium. Telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel would present with bloody stools.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with pyloric stenosis, which is caused by hypertrophic muscularis externa of the pylorus leading to obstruction. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization would cause duodenal obstruction but typically presents earlier in life. Failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum is associated with Hirschsprung disease and presents with constipation. Telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel, or intussusception, presents with colicky abdominal pain and bloody stools.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), which is marked by projectile vomiting, non-bilious, non-bloody vomit, and visible peristalsis. The palpable olive-shaped mass is a classic sign of IHPS. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization causes duodenal atresia, failure of neural crest cell migration causes Hirschsprung's disease, and telescoping of small bowel into large bowel causes intussusception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pyloric stenosis, with projectile vomiting, delay in capillary refill, and a palpable olive-shaped mass on palpation. Among the options, only hypertrophic muscularis externa is associated with pyloric stenosis. Failure of duodenal lumen recanalization can cause duodenal atresia, failure of neural crest cell migration into the rectum can cause Hirschsprung's disease, and telescoping of the small bowel into the large bowel can cause intussusception.
